## 1. How exposure is measured in the field  

| Quantity | Unit | What it describes | Typical instrument |
|----------|------|-------------------|--------------------|
| **Power‑density (PD)** | µW cm⁻² or mW m⁻² | Energy flow per unit area of the incident RF wave (what you “feel” on the skin). | Broadband isotropic E‑field probe + spectrum analyzer (e.g., Narda‑EFA, Rohde & Schwarz). |
| **Electric‑field strength (E)** | V m⁻¹ | Amplitude of the electric component of the wave; related to PD by  PD = E² / (120π) in free space. | Same probe as above. |
| **Specific Absorption Rate (SAR)** | W kg⁻¹ | Rate at which energy is absorbed by body tissue (used for devices that are held close to the body). | Calculated from PD using validated computational models (e.g., IEEE/IEC 62704). |

Field surveys of 5‑G deployments always report **PD** because that is what is directly measured at a distance from the antenna. SAR is derived from PD only when the source is very close to the body (e.g., a handset or a mm‑wave small‑cell panel on a street lamp).
